Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2008 01:10AM priz47 wrote: Most surgeons don't even look at your feet, so toenail polishis Ok. They just don't wantyou wearing dark nail polish (like blue, purple, black) bcs then the oximeter cannot read through the color. I plan on getting a pedicure before hand so my feet feel soft and look pretty. I never do my finger nails, as washing hands and working in a hospital plays havoc on nail polish....And I never even thought abt wearing makeup to the hospital!!! I figured it was one les thing to worry about! Now my hair on the other hand.. D

Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed sandee107 priz47

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2008 06:07PM priz47 wrote: I had a unilateral TRAM done in July. The surgery was much easier than I thought it would be. Long yes, but good pain control afterwards. I am pleased with the results. I opted for a reduction on my good side, as I was a 36DD and am now just a C. I did not request a reduction, but my PS knew he could not make a breast "that big" with what I had. So plwease double check with your doctor, so you do not wake up surprised! I just finished chemo, no rads for me so I was able to do it in one surgery. I have minor revisions and a nipple to do also. It is hard to make the deciosn about a unilat or bilat. I was OK with MRI every 6 months as I wanted to keep what I could. Having feeling on one side was an important factor to me. You have to listen to the doctors, then make a decision you can live with. I am happy I did what I did and have no regrets. D

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2008 12:24AM priz47 wrote: Many doctors will not put you under when they inject the dye bcs they do not know how long it will take to reach the nodes. That is what my radiologist told me when he did mine. It can take as long as 8 hours and that is tool long to be under anesthesia waiting. It was extremely painful and I had 4 injections. i told him if he needs to do it again, just remove the darn nodes! That was worse than the lumpectomy and SNB incision. Hopefuuly the mastectomy won't be too bad. awaiting to see onc and PS this week and maybe have answers to my BRCA test. I HATE to wait! D

Posts.Content: priz47 wrote: I'm looking for information on the benefit of having chemo with ILC. The only articles i found were about neoadjunct chemo. I had a lumpectomy with 0.6cm tumor and mastetomy with 0.9cm tumor. Onc said chemo was my decision. I am in the 'grey area'. What i don't understand is why the 2 are not added together. Chemo is a definite if tumor was 1cm. To me, 0.9cm is awful close. i have been trying to do research as i told my onc I would give her answer on Monday. It's a 3% decrease in reoccurrance if I do chemo. part of me feels like I need to dowhatever possible to prevent this from reocurring and keep my healthy breast. i know ILC tends to mirror in opposite breast. Anyone have any research or ideas? D Dx 4/22/2008, ILC, 1cm, Stage II, Grade 3, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2008 01:28AM priz47 wrote: That is a serious complication. Your chemo drug was not going into the vein, but into the surrounding tissue. How often are they monitoring you? Did they talk abt taking the port out? D
Posts.Title: Serious Chemo Complication ruth599 ruth599

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2009 09:59AM priz47 wrote: My cancer was found on MRI after a clean mamogram and US. The first MRI was diagnostic, where they found the cancer. I am claustrophobic and was having a hard time lying still and not freaking out.( I now know to take Xanax before any MRI for me) The MRI biopsy was much easier, as the radiologist who was doing it talked to me the whole time. There was a nurse in there with him, both dressed up like in surgery. He gave me a shot localy where he would do the incision. It was maybe a 1/2 inch-1 inch long. You can feel some pressure, but no pain. He only put a sterisrip on it followed by a large bandaid. I was amazed that when i sat up, I could see the blood on the towels. I just wasn't thinking straight, for of course there would be blood! I did ice it for 24 hours afterwards. It wasn't painful, just uncomfortable. They do leave a 'marker' in you for the lumpectomy. (I started with lumpectomy, but ended up with mastectomy) You can always PM me for specific questions. Good luck! D

Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2009 10:40AM priz47 wrote: Really sounds like you have had a bad time! You are probably over the worst of it, thank goodness. Do you have gauze where you are bleeding? I would keep track of how many times you need to change that and let his nurse know. If its alot, I'd call everyday! That way they can track it. Watch for any yellow/green foul-smelling drainage and a fever. All signs of infection. How big was your fat necrosis and what did your PS do to fix it? I have one that is marble ( large one) size. I do not go back till July but am anxious abt what he will suggest or do D
Posts.Title: Complications after TRAM revision - Help! pameliza Kathy_K

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2008 12:09PM priz47 wrote: Another nurse here! But I work with kids so I am no expert in oncology. Did you know that there is a higher incidence of breast cancer in nurses who work night shift?? How long did we all do that to 'pay our dues'? I have worked with children with cancer, my own son included. That makes me think I know stuff. I usually do not tell anyone I am a nurse unless asked outright. It was amazing how I was 'feared' when I was in the hospital with a collapsed lung-all because I was a nurse! The only good part is my onc knows I work in a hospital, so my counts are done weekly with the understanding that I may not be able to work. I also have brought someone (good friend, fellow nurse) to all my appointments. A different perspective is good to have. I go back to work next week and hope al my coworkers understand. especialy when I walk into a room and cannot remember why I went in there! As fellow nurses, anyone know something about 3D tattoos? I am thinking of that instead of more surgery. Still need to talk to PS abt it. Nice meeting y'al! D
